author: @clearthinking5441
text: Hi Harrison, I am a great fan of your work. However, I think this introduction to classes is not very good. It would be better if you gave a clearer outline at the beginning as to what classes are actually used for. Also keywords (instance, method, object, attributes) are used too quickly without a proper explanation as to what they mean (this is an intro!). I get that you are trying to use an example to illustrate how classes are used but you don't even explain at the beginning what you want Blob object to actually do!

author: @ryanrowland
text: I'm new to Python, I started learning about 3 weeks ago.  I've written several basic apps using skills I picked up from your basics series for which I'm not sure what the correct term is (Procedural? I basically just tell it what I want it to do in order of when I want it to do it, while also defining functions to avoid repeating code) without much trouble. I actually felt pretty confident that I was picking it up pretty quickly as doing it that way all seemed fairly logical to me.  However, I have just finished watching this tutorial series and by the end of the OOP stuff I feel like my brain as melted and that it all just went in one ear and out the other - it just didn't click like everything else seemed to.  What would you suggest would be the best way to try and get my head around OOP?

author: @lucien04100
text: It seems to me that  the 2nd and 3rd line in the definition of the 'move' method is kinda redundant, if the 2nd line to 5th line are replaced with:      self.x += random.randrange(-1,2) self.y += random.randrange(-1,2)

author: @tiobraulio
text: Where sould be imported libraries in clases?, inside the definition or outside?  Suppose as example you define a new class that will plot some data stored in the class. In the main script you wont use any plot function, all plotting function are used as methods inside de class... What would be better? Import before defining the class or inside the class definition?

text: Nice vid but I got a cpl of questions.  1 - I have seen people use a decorator called " @property" with class methods, what is a decorator and why is " @property" used.  2 - why define 2 variables to the same value ?
